subject: Re: [junit] Is it really neccessery to use Junit with some kind of IDE ?
msgSnippet: ... Simon, I m intrigued.  On many of my projects, I have a single suite of fast tests that cover all the classes in my project; no need for a suite for each
messageBody:
Simon Chappell wrote:

> > Why not have it both ways? In my latest projects, I have a test suite
> > that runs "all fast tests" in under a minute; very useful when just
> > running one or two test cases doesn't cover all your changes.
> > However, the build also runs completely independant on build machine
> > via ant, which isn't very hard to do if you just get it working from
> > the start. So you can get the CI and all that brings with it, plus
> > the feedback on a local developer's IDE before they check in.
>
> I think that working on one object and one test at a time is enough. I
> suspect that the effort to create a suite for each object you work on
> would get tedious. If you're working on a highly connected object, it
> would be better to refactor it rather than cater to it.

Simon,

I'm intrigued. On many of my projects, I have a single suite of fast
tests that cover all the classes in my project; no need for a suite for
each class. I find that this often allows me to catch accidental
dependencies, and also allows me to have the structure of my tests not
be rigidly isomorphic to the structure of my code. Would this strategy
work on your projects?

David Saff
